name: General Knowledge 5 Multiple Choice Quiz | Mixed 25 Questions | 25 Questions

questions.text: The Taj Mahal is made from which material?
questions.explanation:
White marble.

	The white marble mausoleum in central India was built (1632-43) by the emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz Mahal. It stands in Agra on the Jumna River.

questions.text: Name the river in south-east Australia which rises in New South Wales?
questions.explanation: Snowy.

questions.text: Where would you find the 'Sea of Serenity' and the 'Sea of Tranquillity'?
questions.explanation:
On the moon.

	Apollo 11 landed on the Sea of Tranquillity.

questions.text: Name the state capital of North Carolina.
questions.explanation:
Raleigh.

	Columbus is the capital of Ohio, Montgomery the capital of Alabama and Bismarck the capital of North Dakota.

questions.text: Alexander Selkirk was shipwrecked on the Juan Fernandez Islands (now owned by Chile) which gave the idea for which novel?
questions.explanation: 'Robinson Crusoe'.

questions.text: Which country is called 'Little Venice'?
questions.explanation:
Venezuela.

	Stilt houses reminded the first European settlers of Venice.

questions.text: Name the 1935 novel by C.S. Forester.
questions.explanation:
'The African Queen'.

	British author Cecil Scott Forester was most famous for his 12 novel saga about Horatio Hornblower set during the Napoleonic Wars.

questions.text: One of the world's biggest selling acts of the late 1990's features this headdress-wearing vocalist of the group Jamiroquai. Name this artiste who dated Denise Van Outen.
questions.explanation: Jay Kay.

questions.text: Name the British statesman and one of the founders of the Conservative Party who established the London police force (1828) when he was home secretary. Sir Robert ...
questions.explanation:
Peel.

	The nickname 'Peelers' or 'Bobbies' were derived from his name. He is also remembered as a reforming Prime Minister (1841-6).

questions.text: Where would you find the magnificent 'Blue Mosque'?
questions.explanation:
Istanbul.

	The Blue Mosque is also known as the Sultan Ahmet mosque. It is called the Blue Mosque on account of the predominantly blue and green tilework and painted decoration of its interior.

questions.text: Which rare amphibian's name means 'water monster' in the Aztec language?
questions.explanation:
Axolotl.

	It is an aquatic salamander found in high altitude freshwater lakes in Mexico.

questions.text: Where can visitors sit in the cafes of St. Mark's Square and overlook the famous bell tower and domes of the Basilica of St Mark?
questions.explanation:
Venice.

	'Basilica' means 'church'.

questions.text: Who is the film director of the 'Scream' movies?
questions.explanation:
Wes Craven.

	David Cronenberg's films include 'Scanners' (1980), 'The Fly' (1986), 'Naked Lunch' (1991) and 'Crash' (1996). John Carpenter's films include 'Halloween' (1978) and 'The Thing' (1982). Brian de Palma's films include 'Carrie' (1976), 'The Untouchables' (1987) and 'Snake Eyes' (1998)

questions.text: The ruins of the Inca city of Machu Picchu are in which country?
questions.explanation:
Peru.

	The best-preserved of the Inca settlements is situated on an Andean mountain saddle, 6750 feet above sea level. The ruins were discovered in 1911 by American explorer Hiram Bingham who dubbed it the 'lost city of the Incas' but nobody knows why the Incas abandoned it.

questions.text: Beautiful painted wooden dolls are a traditional Russian toy where each one contains a series of smaller dolls inside it. They are called 'matruschka' which means ...
questions.explanation: Little mother.

questions.text: Name the world's deepest lake and the largest freshwater feature in Asia.
questions.explanation:
Lake Baikal.

	This lake is fed by numerous small rivers and is situated in south Siberia where the Trans-Siberian Railway runs along its southern edge.

questions.text: Which novelist left her last book, 'Sanditon', unfinished at her death?
questions.explanation:
Jane Austen.

	Jane Austen never married and spent most of her life quietly at home with her family. 'Pride and Prejudice' was her first full-length novel and 'Sanditon' her sixth book.

questions.text: Why did Vincent Van Gogh cut off his ear?
questions.correct: In remorse for attacking his friend Paul Gauguin with a razor
options: To paint another self portrait of which had become an obsession.
Out of frustration as he couldn't sell any of his paintings
Attempted suicide as he was a haemophiliac
questions.explanation: In remorse for attacking his friend Paul Gauguin with a razor.

questions.text: What was Charles Dickens first novel of 1836?
questions.explanation:
The Pickwick Papers.

	'Oliver Twist' (1839), 'The Old Curiosity Shop' (1841) and 'Barnaby Rudge' (1841)

questions.text: Mrs. Beeton was associated with a cookery book and wrote 'Mrs. Beeton's Book of Household Management'. What was her first name?
questions.explanation: Isabella.

questions.text: Mount Bromo is an active volcano and is one of a chain of volcanoes called 'The Ring of Fire'. On which island can it be found?
questions.explanation: Java.

questions.text: The musical instrument the 'Rondador' is better known as ...
questions.explanation:
Pan pipes.

	The notes are produced by blowing across the tops of a series of hollow tubes made of wood, bamboo or reeds.

questions.text: What was the name of the doctor who with colleague Sir A. Bradford Hill, were the first to prove the link between smoking and lung cancer. Sir Richard ...?
questions.explanation: Doll.

questions.text: The snow capped slopes of Mount Fuji is Japan's highest mountain which has inspired artists for centuries. Its many shrines and temples are visited by pilgrims. In what year did the volcano last erupt?
Devil's Island, which is just north of Kourou in French Guiana, was a harsh French penal colony. The island is now a tourist resort but in what year was the prison closed?
questions.explanation:
1953.

	Hope you enjoyed the quiz and learnt something new.
